entries.text:
This ring was named after Havel the Rock, Lord Gwyn's old battlefield compatriot.
Havel's men wore the ring to express faith in their leader and to carry a heavier load.

The rare gem called tearstone has the uncanny ability to sense imminent death.
This red tearstone from Carim boosts the attack of its wearer when in danger.

Ring granted to those bound by the Darkmoon Blade covenant. Answer Dark Sun Gwyndolin's summoning.
Gwyndolin, all too aware of his repulsive, frail appearance, created the illusion of a sister Gwynevere, who helps him guard over Anor Londo. An unmasking of these deities would be tantamount to blasphemy.

Ring granted to those bound by the Forest Hunter covenant. Answer Alvina's summoning.
The white cat Alvina speaks a human tongue and has lived since the early Age of Fire. Alvina was a trusted friend of Knight Artorias and the Great Wolf Sif.

This ancient ring, engraved with a large green flower, is of unknown origin.
Hastens the regeneration of stamina.

Stoneplates, the symbol of a true knight, grant the strength to face various hardships.
The red stoneplate symbolizes fire, and boosts defence against flame.

Stoneplates, the symbol of a true knight, grant the strength to face various hardships.
The yellow stoneplate symbolizes thunder, and boosts defence against lightning.

Stoneplates, the symbol of a true knight, grant the strength to face various hardships.
The blue stoneplate symbolizes souls, and boosts defence against magic.

Stoneplates, the symbol of a true knight, grant the strength to face various hardships.
The precious rare speckled stoneplate grants a small boost to defence against magic, flame, and lightning.

One of the infamous bite rings commissioned by Sir Arstor of Carim.
Despite the dreadful rumors surrounding its creation, this ring is an unmistakable asset, in its ability to help prevent bleeding.

One of the infamous bite rings commissioned by Sir Arstor of Carim.
Despite the dreadful rumors surrounding its creation, this ring is an unmistakable asset, in its ability to help prevent poison.

Ring made of an ancient tiny red jewel. Grants small increase to HP.
Rings grant powers large and small. Their discovery, and effective use, can make one's journey easier.

One of the infamous bite rings commissioned by Sir Arstor of Carim.
Despite the dreadful rumors surrounding its creation, this ring is an unmistakable asset, in its ability to help prevent curses.

A divine ring entrusted to the head bishop of the Way of White and apostle to Allfather Lloyd, uncle to Lord Gwyn. It grants additional attunement slots.
The head bishop of the Way of White is the guardian of law and caste, and one of the great royals of Thorolund.

A special ring granted to only the most accomplished sorcerers at Vinheim Dragon School.
The ring is engraved with an everlasting dragon, and boosts the strength of sorceries.

This magic crown-shaped ring was granted to princess Dusk of Oolacile upon her birth.
The ringstone allows its wearer to cast additional sorceries, but at the cost of one-half of HP.

One of the special rings granted to the four knights of Gwyn. The Hornet Ring belonged to the Lord's Blade Ciaran.
By boosting critical attacks, its wearer can annihilate foes, as Ciaran's dagger laid waste to Lord Gwyn's enemies.

One of the special rings granted to the four knights of Gwyn. The Hawk Ring belonged to Hawkeye Gough, who led the Greatarchers.
Boosts bow range, so that arrows fly like they were shot by Gough's great bow, which took down high-flying dragons.

This ring belonged to the Knight King Rendal. It grants its wearer protection by boosting defense against physical attacks.
Of the many legends surrounding the Knight King Rendal, one of the more well-known speaks of his standing down a giant drake and slashing it to pieces.

The serpent is an imperfect dragon and symbol of the Undead. Its habit of devouring prey even larger than itself has led to an association with gluttony.
This gold ring, engraved with the serpent, boosts its wearer's item discovery, so that more items can be amassed.

The serpent is an imperfect dragon and symbol of the Undead. Its habit of devouring prey even larger than itself has led to an association with gluttony.
This silver ring, engraved with the serpent, rewards its wearer with additional souls for each kill.

This ring was secretly worn by a certain surreptitious sorcerer at Vinheim Dragon School.
The ring is engraved with an everlasting dragon in silent slumber, and masks all sound emitting from its wearer.

Those who befriend Alvina are given this mysterious ring. It resembles a pearl with its robust pure-white fog.
The ring camouflages its wearer's presence, helping to prevent detection.

This iron ring was used to shackle the guilty. It is terribly rusted, and faintly stained with blood.
Those who find this strange ring to their liking will be pleased to find it easier to gain footing on poor ground such as swamps.

This mystical ring was created in a sacrificial rite of Velka, the Goddess of Sin.
Its wearer will lose nothing upon death, but the ring itself breaks.

This mystical ring was created in a sacrificial rite of Velka, the Goddess of Sin. The magenta-shaded ring is especially rare.
Its wearer will lose nothing upon death, and will be freed from any curse whatsoever, but the ring itself breaks.

This special ring crafted in an Eastern land is made of gold, but with a wood grain crest on its surface.
Agents of subterfuge in this faraway land are particularly fond of the dark gold wood grain, which greatly alters its wearer's rolling action.

This ring is granted to those who enter a Covenant with Gwynevere, daughter of Lord Gwyn and the Princess of Sunlight. This slightly warm ring boosts the synergy of miracles.
The Princess of Sunlight Gwynevere left Anor Londo along with many other deities, and later became wife to Flame God Flann.

This black diamond ring is granted to those who enter a Covenant with Velka, the Goddess of Sin. It automatically counterattacks when its wearer inflicts sustained damage.
Velka the Goddess of Sin is an eccentric witch versed in various secret rites, an

This ring belonged to the seal guardian of New Londo. It prevents its wearer's discovery by cursed ghosts.
There were once three guardians of the seal, but two of them tired of their eternal task, and left New Londo long ago.

Old ring from an old witch.
Engraved minutely with indecipherable script, but seemingly useless.

This ring symbolizes Knight Artorias's covenant with the beasts of the Abyss.
Its wearer, like Artorias himself, can traverse the Abyss.

An orange ring enchanted by a witch. Reduces lava damage.
Since his sores were inflamed by lava from birth, his witch sisters gave him this special ring. But fool that he is, he readily dropped it, and from that spot, a terrible centipede demon was born.

The ring of a lost miracle of New Londo. This ring takes damage in place of its wearer, but has a fixed chance of breaking.
As evidenced by this ring, the culture of New Londo was unique, and its flooding is widely considered to be a great loss.

A special ring granted to only the most accomplished sorcerers at Vinheim Dragon School.
The ring is engraved with a lingering dragon, and boosts the length of the effects of sorceries.

According to legend, this ring contains the spirit of the evil eye, a dark beast which assaulted Astora.
The strength of the evil eye does not waver, and HP is absorbed from fallen enemies.

A ring symbolizing the favor and protection of the goddess Fina, known in legend to possess "fateful beauty."
This ring boosts its wearer's HP, stamina, and max equipment load, but breaks if ever removed.

One of the special rings granted to the four knights of Gwyn. The Leo Ring belonged to Ornstein the Dragonslayer.
This ring strengthens counters with pierce weapons. His lugged spear is said to have sliced a boulder in two.

This special ring crafted in an Eastern land is made of gold, but with a wood grain crest on its surface.
The ring slows the loss of weapon durability and is particularly useful to bearers of delicate swords crafted in the East.

One of the special rings granted to the four knights of Gwyn. The Wolf Ring belongs to Artorias the Abysswalker.
Artorias had an unbendable will of steel, and was unmatched with a greatsword.

The rare gem called tearstone has the uncanny ability to sense imminent death.
This blue tearstone from Catarina boosts the defence of its wearer when in danger.

Lord Gwyn's firstborn, who inherited the sunlight, once wore this ancient ring. Boosts the strength of miracles.
Lord Gwyn's firstborn was a god of war, but his foolishness led to a loss of the annals, and rescinding of his deific status. Today, even his name is not known.

This ring is granted to adherents of Gwyndolin, Darkmoon deity and last born of Gwyn, Lord of Sunlight. Grants additional magic attunement slots.
The Dark Sun Gwyndolin is the only remaining deity in Anor Londo. His followers are few, but their tasks are of vital importance.

A silver pendant depicting the Darkmoon and a sword, the crest of the Darkmoon Knights, the original Blue Sentinels.
Pledge one’s self to the Darkmoon Faithful covenant, and swear an oath to the silver light of protection.
Boosts Magic damage by 5% whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Proof of a Concord Kept from enemies.
When a member of the Way of Blue faces a dark spirit, the Blades of the Darkmoon, by an ancient accord, help to root out the invader.

Ancient medallion depicting the crest of a wolf. Symbolizes the pact with the Old Wolf of Farron.
Pledge one’s self to the Watchdogs of Farron, and bind yourself to the fate of the forest you now protect.
Reduces weapon stamina consumption by 10% whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Wolf's Blood Swordgrass from enemies.
The Watchdogs ensure that the warriors sleep in serenity, by taking the form of loyal spirits and hunting down those who would trespass the woods of Farron.

The holy symbol of the Cathedral of the Deep, and crest of those who see beyond fire to the age of deep waters.
Pledge one’s self to the Cathedral of the Deep covenant, and embrace the coming tides of dark.
Boosts Dark damage by 5% whilst worn.
Increases the collection of Human Dregs from enemies.
The Faithful ensure that Aldrich, Devourer of Gods, remains undisturbed, by taking the form of loyal spirits and hunting down those who would trespass the ruined cathedral.

An ancient talisman depicting a holy symbol bestowed upon the Warriors of Sunlight. Tales of their unity inspire powerful miracles to this day.
Pledge one’s self to Warrior of Sunlight, and engage in cooperation most jolly.
Boosts Lightning damage by 5% whilst worn.
Increases the collection of Sunlight Medal from enemies.
Warriors of Sunlight are brilliantly beaming co-operators who place their golden signatures to help those in need, for it is their duty to deliver a great conquest to their summoner.

A malformed vertebra found by the mad, with a queer symbol on its inside, proof of the shackles of the gods.
Pledge one’s self to the Mound-maker covenant, and succumb to the madness of existence.
Increases Physical damage by 5% whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Vertebra Shackle from enemies.
The mound-makers wish only to add to their mounds, becoming mad spirits whether summoned as co-operators or invaders. They are blithe to those around them, for in their minds, any kill might lead to another shackle.

The emblem carried by the Brotherhood of Assassins. Skilled in infiltration and subterfuge, as well as infamous assassins, they could reportedly kill any target, for the right price.
Pledge one’s self to the Assassin’s Brotherhood covenant, and receive greater rewards for each kill.
Increases weapon damage by 3% and grants additional stamina regen.
Enables the collection of Bloody Coins from enemies.

A smouldering tome containing the chronicles of pyromantic pilgrimages to lost Izalith. The fire of such a tome is cool to the touch, and never wavers, unlike many who attempted such a journey.
Pledge one’s self to the Followers of Flame covenant, and embrace the primal power that fire brings.
Reduces FP consumption of conjurations by 5%.
Enables the collection of Smoldering Stones from enemies.

Sacred seal of Archdeacon Klimt, who served Rosaria, Mistress of Blood and Mother of Rebirth. Those devout to her find themselves blessed with the power of blood magic.
Pledge one’s self to the Rosaria’s Fingers covenant, and seek power in blood, wherever it lies.
Restores 2 HP over time whilst worn.
Enables the collection of Pale Tongues from enemies.
Rosaria's Fingers collect tongues in her name. Some do it to be reborn; others do it to help comfort their voiceless goddess.

A scroll depicting the mark of the School of the Dragon. This prestigious Vinheim academy was home to many different styles of magic, and claimed to be able to cater to each, regardless of noble birth.
Pledge one’s self to the Students of the Dragon covenant, but beware the arrogance that such magic brings.
Increases max FP by 3%.
Enables the collection of Arcane Crystals from enemies.

A worn tome with a black crow on the cover, the teachings of Velka, Goddess of Sin, have existed since the time of the first flame. The ability to purge oneself, and others, of sin is a gift only granted by a goddess.
Pledge one’s self to the Children of Velka covenant, and become absolved of your dark sins.
Increases casting speed by 15.
Enables the collection of Murky Sediment from enemies.

A band of light that symbolizes the Way of White. The light can be found glowing on the skin of its followers, though the sight of such a band has become far more uncommon.
Pledge one’s self to the Way of White covenant, and bring light in the name of the old gods.
Reduces FP consumption of miracles by 5%.
Enables the collection of Glimmering Dust from enemies.

Faded sheepskin parchment depicting the Darkmoon and a sword. The Blue Sentinels are bound to the Blades of the Darkmoon, who shall come to aid them in their time of need.
Pledge one’s self to the Blue Sentinels covenant, and aid those who hold the other half of this accord.
Increases casting speed by 15.
Enables the collection of Proof of a Concord Kept from enemies.
When a member of the Way of Blue is threatened by a dark spirit, the Blue Sentinels, in compliance with an ancient accord, assume the form of blue spirits, and help to root out the leader.

Pale blue sheepskin parchment detailing the moon of an ancient accord.
Pledge one’s self to the Way of Blue, and benefit from an ancient accord, forged during the first era of flame.
Increases max HP by 5% whilst worn.
Enables the collection of random consumables from enemies.
Members of the Way of Blue are the beneficiaries of an ancient accord. When a dark spirit threatens them, a blue spirit will grant them assistance, and help root out the invader.

The mark of Old Forossa and its allies. Old Forossa is named as such, for a New Forossa exists in its place, ruled over by a descendant of the Lord of Sunlight.
Pledge one’s self to the Forossan Sages covenant, and learn to master the most violent of storms.
Increases spell casting speed by 20 while worn.
Enables the collection of Storm Debris from enemies.

A frozen memory of loss and betrayal, this pendant is held dear by those who embrace the inverted flame of cryomancy. This precious emblem echoes unspeakable sorrow.
Pledge one’s self to the Forlorn Dissenters covenant, and seek vengeance in the name of inverted flame.
Increases dark damage by 5% while worn.
Enables the collection of frozen tears from enemies.

A small burning ember of the flames of Chaos. Though faint, this fire still burns, even though its link to Chaos was severed. A testament to the true resilience of Chaos, embraced by those who follow the practices of lost Izalith.
Pledge one’s self to the Izalith Disciples covenant, and embrace what remains of Chaos, stoking its embers to an ever greater blaze.
Increases fire damage by 5% while worn.
Enables the collection of Chaos Remnants from enemies.

Holy symbol of the Allfather Lloyd and those who hunt the mindless undead in his name. Lloyd does not claim divinity, but his followers believe him to be so, and gain strength in their faith as a result.
Pledge one’s self to the Lloyd’s Devout covenant, and protect what remains of humanity from the restless dead.
Increases casting speed by 20 while worn.
Enables the collection of divine relics from enemies.

Ashes of reborn warriors, in service of a Firekeeper. Born again from the ashes, many warriors found kinship among the Firekeepers. Within their arms, some unkindled ash found a reason to fight.
Pledge one’s self to the Unkindled Warriors covenant, and stand with the Firekeepers and their holy mission.
Increases physical attack power of weapons by 5%.
Enables the collection of standard titanite from enemies.

An ancient stone with thin smoke rising from the engraving. A piece of a demon who lost their connection with Chaos, geomancers draw their inspiration and teachings from such a terrible source.
Pledge one’s self to the Stray Wanderers covenant, and walk the path of lost demons.
Increases casting speed by 15.
Enables the collection of Glimmering Dust from enemies.

A scrap of an ancient banner once depicting the heraldic insignia of the Order of the Lion. A keepsake of those that endured the calamity that befell Old Forossa.
Pledge one’s self to the Forossan Survivors covenant, and follow the path to the eternal sky.
Increases casting speed by 15.
Enables the collection of Glimmering Dust from enemies.

An alchemical text describing formulae and mixtures. The practice of alchemy is uncommon, and originates from a far land, but the creation of such materials can greatly aid one on their journey.
Pledge one’s self to the Apprentice Alchemist covenant, and gain training in the oft neglected sciences.
Increases luck by 5.
Enables the collection of Alchemy Reagents from enemies.

An advanced alchemical text describing complicated formulae and solutions. Those who adhere to the path of alchemy unlock greater secrets as their understanding increases, allowing them to create even more potent mixtures.
Pledge one’s self to the Journeyman Alchemist covenant, and further your path of scientific discovery.
Increases luck by 5.
Enables the collection of Greater Alchemy Reagents from enemies.

A ciphered text containing recipes and formulae that only the most skilled students of the craft can discern. These hidden teachings are baffling to most, both for their complexity and potency.
Pledge one’s self to the Master Alchemist covenant, and further your path of scientific discovery.
Increases luck by 5 and increases item discovery by 5%.
Enables the collection of Master Alchemy Reagents from enemies.

A golden emblem of lost Oolacile. Many of Oolacile’s discoveries were thought lost in the modern age. Dusk was careful to preserve such knowledge, and passed it on to many pilgrims of light, who shared such knowledge with reverence.
Pledge one’s self to the Oolacile Survivors covenant, and begin your pilgrimage along the path of light.
Increases max FP by 5%.
Enables the collection of Sacred Idols from enemies.

The symbol of the Druidic Conclave of Vinheim, a medallion of greeni metal, dirt stained and bearing the inscription of essence. Druids learned to control the very energy of life, and though such a magic was shunned in Vinheim, those that discovered it were not.
Pledge one’s self to The Conclave covenant, and gain the power and favor of the natural world.
Increases maximum FP by 5%.
Allows for the collection of Essence Shards from enemies.

The sarcophagal pendant of the ancient tombs. Once used in the pursuit of the eyes of death, it now acts to identify the followers of the First of the Dead. These new Gravelords act in Nito’s stead, controlling and quelling the undead.
Pledge one’s self to the Minions of the Gravelord covenant, and rediscover the ancient power of necromancy.
Increases maximum FP by 5%.
Allows for the collection of Gravelord Relics from enemies.

A band of sunlight that symbolizes the Seekers of Sunlight.
Increases casting speed by 15.
Enables the collection of Sacred Idols from enemies.

Allies turned to enemies of war, and imprisoned by their king and the flame, the creatures known as giants have had a tumultuous relationship with humans from the very start. Those who stand with them are rare, but are known to receive a fraction of their tremendous strength.
Pledge one’s self to the Clan of Giants, and bring the unshackled might of your adopted brethren back to the world.
Increases overall weapon attack power by 5%.
Enables the collection of Broken Manacles from enemies.

A generations-old ring set with a small red jewel. Raises maximum HP.
Rings have unique powers, and their discovery will do much to ease a wearisome journey.

A generations-old ring set with a small red jewel. Raises maximum HP.
Rings have unique powers, and their discovery will do much to ease a wearisome journey.

A generations-old ring set with a small red jewel. Raises maximum HP.
Rings have unique powers, and their discovery will do much to ease a wearisome journey.

A generations-old ring set with a small red jewel. Raises maximum HP.
Rings have unique powers, and their discovery will do much to ease a wearisome journey.

This old ring is named for its decorative green blossom, but its luster is long since faded.
Raises stamina recovery speed.

This old ring is named for its decorative green blossom, but its luster is long since faded.
Raises stamina recovery speed.

This old ring is named for its decorative green blossom, but its luster is long since faded.
Raises stamina recovery speed.

A ring for warriors keen on heavy accoutrements. Increases maximum equip load.
This ring was named after Havel the Rock, the battlefield compatriot of Gwyn, the First Lord.
The art of war has been a constant since ages past, and those who would follow in Havel's footsteps are no fewer now than in his own day.

A ring for warriors keen on heavy accoutrements. Increases maximum equip load.
This ring was named after Havel the Rock, the battlefield compatriot of Gwyn, the First Lord.
The art of war has been a constant since ages past, and those who would follow in Havel's footsteps are no fewer now than in his own day.

A ring for warriors keen on heavy accoutrements. Increases maximum equip load.
This ring was named after Havel the Rock, the battlefield compatriot of Gwyn, the First Lord.
The art of war has been a constant since ages past, and those who would follow in Havel's footsteps are no fewer now than in his own day.

A ring symbolizing the favor of the Goddess Fina, whose "fateful beauty" is mentioned in legend.
True to the fickle nature of Fina's favor, her ring increases max HP, stamina, and maximum equip load.

A ring symbolizing the favor of the Goddess Fina, whose "fateful beauty" is mentioned in legend.
True to the fickle nature of Fina's favor, her ring increases max HP, stamina, and maximum equip load.

A ring symbolizing the favor of the Goddess Fina, whose "fateful beauty" is mentioned in legend.
True to the fickle nature of Fina's favor, her ring increases max HP, stamina, and maximum equip load.

Ring of the Knight King of ancient legend. Increases physical damage absorption by 25%.
The Knight King was said to be lined with steel on the inside, such that even the talons of mighty dragons did him little harm.

Ring of the Knight King of ancient legend. Increases physical damage absorption by 12%.
The Knight King was said to be lined with steel on the inside, such that even the talons of mighty dragons did him little harm.

Ring of the Knight King of ancient legend. Increases physical damage absorption by 14%.
The Knight King was said to be lined with steel on the inside, such that even the talons of mighty dragons did him little harm.

Ring of the Knight King of ancient legend. Increases physical damage absorption by 16%.
The Knight King was said to be lined with steel on the inside, such that even the talons of mighty dragons did him little harm.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and red stoneplates are granted to those who valiantly face Chaos.
Increases fire damage absorption by 65%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and red stoneplates are granted to those who valiantly face Chaos.
Increases fire damage absorption by 70%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and red stoneplates are granted to those who valiantly face Chaos.
Increases fire damage absorption by 75%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and red stoneplates are granted to those who valiantly face Chaos.
Increases fire damage absorption by 80%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and yellow stoneplates are granted to those who would become dragons.
Increases lightning damage absorption by 65%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and yellow stoneplates are granted to those who would become dragons.
Increases lightning damage absorption by 70%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and yellow stoneplates are granted to those who would become dragons.
Increases lightning damage absorption by 75%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and yellow stoneplates are granted to those who would become dragons.
Increases lightning damage absorption by 80%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and blue stoneplates are granted to the royal palace guards.
Increases magic damage absorption by 65%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and blue stoneplates are granted to the royal palace guards.
Increases magic damage absorption by 70%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and blue stoneplates are granted to the royal palace guards.
Increases magic damage absorption by 75%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and blue stoneplates are granted to the royal palace guards.
Increases magic damage absorption by 80%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and dark purple stoneplates are granted to Undead knights.
Increases dark damage absorption by 65%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and dark purple stoneplates are granted to Undead knights.
Increases dark damage absorption by 70%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and dark purple stoneplates are granted to Undead knights.
Increases dark damage absorption by 75%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and dark purple stoneplates are granted to Undead knights.
Increases dark damage absorption by 80%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and speckled stoneplates are granted to those who face an endless journey.
Slightly increases magic, lightning, fire and dark damage absorption by 20%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and speckled stoneplates are granted to those who face an endless journey.
Slightly increases magic, lightning, fire and dark damage absorption by 23%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and speckled stoneplates are granted to those who face an endless journey.
Slightly increases magic, lightning, fire and dark damage absorption by 26%.

Stoneplates are symbols of true knights, and speckled stoneplates are granted to those who face an endless journey.
Slightly increases magic, lightning, fire and dark damage absorption by 30%.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Grants bleed immunity.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Grants bleed immunity.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Grants poison immunity.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Grants poison immunity.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Grants toxic immunity.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Grants curse immunity.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Raises poison, bleed, frost and curse resist.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

One of the bite rings native to Carim. Raises poison, bleed, frost and curse resist.
The crafting of these rings is forbidden, perhaps owing to a fear of malleable stone. Clerics, however, dabble freely in the art.

This special ring crafted in an Eastern land is made of metal, but with a wood grain crest on its surface. Slows equipment degradation.
Wielders of swords originating in the same region follow a practice of inscribing special words on the blades of their swords, and are naturally drawn to this ring.

This special ring crafted in an Eastern land is made of metal, but with a wood grain crest on its surface. Slows equipment degradation.
Wielders of swords originating in the same region follow a practice of inscribing special words on the blades of their swords, and are naturally drawn to this ring.

This special ring crafted in an Eastern land is made of metal, but with a wood grain crest on its surface. Slows equipment degradation.
Wielders of swords originating in the same region follow a practice of inscribing special words on the blades of their swords, and are naturally drawn to this ring.

A ring engraved with a portrait of a scholar. Increases intelligence.
In Lothric, the Scholar has long been considered one of the Three Pillars of the king's rule, and is therefore master of the Grand Archives.

A ring engraved with a portrait of the High Priestess. Increases faith.
In Lothric, the High Priestess has long been considered one of the Three Pillars of the king's rule. The High Priestess also served as the prince's wet nurse.

A ring set with a large rare tearstone jewel. Temporarily boosts attack when HP is low.
This stone is said to be a tear of mourning of the goddess Caitha, and of course, tears are always more beautiful near death.

A ring set with a large rare tearstone jewel. Temporarily boosts damage absorption when HP is low.
This stone is said to be a tear of sorrow of the goddess Caitha, and of course, tears are always more beautiful near death.

Ring associated with Abysswalker Artorias, one of the Four Knights of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Increases poise.
Artorias had an unbendable will of steel, and was unmatched with a greatsword.

Ring associated with Abysswalker Artorias, one of the Four Knights of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Increases poise.
Artorias had an unbendable will of steel, and was unmatched with a greatsword.

Ring associated with Abysswalker Artorias, one of the Four Knights of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Increases poise.
Artorias had an unbendable will of steel, and was unmatched with a greatsword.

Ring associated with Dragon Slayer Ornstein, one of the Four Knights of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Strengthens thrust weapon counter attacks.
Ornstein was the first knight of the sun's eldest born, and his cross spear is said to have pierced scales made of stone.

This mystical ring was created in a sacrificial rite of Velka, the Goddess of Sin.
Its wearer will lose nothing upon death, but the ring itself breaks.
A sacrifice is only worth as much as the life it spares.

This mystical ring was created in a sacrificial rite of Velka, the Goddess of Sin. This magenta-shaded ring is especially rare.
Its wearer will lose nothing upon death, and will be freed from any curse whatsoever, but the ring itself breaks.
A sacrifice is only worth as much as the life it spares.

Ring given in Vinheim, home of sorcery, when newly ordained as a sorcerer.
Increases all magic damage by 5%.
Apropos to the Dragon School, the seal depicts an everlasting dragon. A young dragon presages the great length of the journey to mastery.

A special ring given to those who are deemed fit to undertake the journey of discovery in Vinheim, home of sorcery.
Increases all magic damage by 15%.
Apropos to the Dragon School, the seal depicts an everlasting dragon. A bellowing dragon symbolizes the true nature of the consummate sorcerer.

Ring said to be chiseled from the bone of a flame salamander by blighted Pyromancers living in the Great Swamp.
Increases all fire damage by 5%.
It is believed that salamanders are the descendants of demons, born of the Chaos Flame, from which Pyromancy is also said to have originated.

The Witch of Izalith and her daughters, scorched by the Flame of Chaos, taught humans the art of pyromancy and offered them this ring.
Increases all fire damage by 15%.
Every pyromancer is familiar with the parable that tells of the witches espousing the need to fear the flame, and teaching the art of pyromancy to men in hopes that they might learn to control it.

A malformed ring given to knights of Carim.
Increases all lightning damage by 5%.
Morne served the goddess Caitha and later became an apostle of the Archbishop. They labored together to provide comfort to the suffering.

Ring of the Sun's first born, who inherited the light of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Increases all lightning damage by 15%.
The Sun's first born was once a god of war, until he was stripped of his stature as punishment for his foolishness. No wonder his very name has slipped from the annals of history.

A special ring given to those who are deemed fit to undertake the journey of discovery in Vinheim, home of sorcery.
Doubles length of spell effect.
Apropos to the Dragon School, the seal depicts an everlasting dragon. A lingering dragon symbolizes the true nature of the consummate sorcerer.

A special ring given to those who are deemed fit to undertake the journey of discovery in Vinheim, home of sorcery.
Extends length of spell effect.
Apropos to the Dragon School, the seal depicts an everlasting dragon. A lingering dragon symbolizes the true nature of the consummate sorcerer.

A special ring given to those who are deemed fit to undertake the journey of discovery in Vinheim, home of sorcery.
Extends length of spell effect.
Apropos to the Dragon School, the seal depicts an everlasting dragon. A lingering dragon symbolizes the true nature of the consummate sorcerer.

A ring given to Farron's Undead Legion by one of the preacher twins, known more commonly as the Crystal Sages.
Shortens spell casting time.
The sorcerers of Farron's Abyss Watchers were known to be lonesome warriors who would only rely upon more pragmatic spells.

A ring given to Farron's Undead Legion by one of the preacher twins, known more commonly as the Crystal Sages.
Shortens spell casting time.
The sorcerers of Farron's Abyss Watchers were known to be lonesome warriors who would only rely upon more pragmatic spells.

A ring given to Farron's Undead Legion by one of the preacher twins, known more commonly as the Crystal Sages.
Shortens spell casting time.
The sorcerers of Farron's Abyss Watchers were known to be lonesome warriors who would only rely upon more pragmatic spells.

Ring of a clandestine guild of sorcerers based in Vinheim, home of sorcery.
Masks the sound of its wearer.
The Dragon School held effective sovereignty over Vinheim, with a great many adept assassins at its disposal.

Leaf-colored crown ring bestowed upon the princess of Oolacile, ancient land of golden sorceries.
Reduces spell FP consumption, but also lowers HP.
Oolacile is synonymous for its lost sorceries, of which the xanthous sorcerers are dedicated scholars. This crown ring is a rare artifact of great magic heritage.

A ring bestowed upon a Carim saint. Allows attunement of additional spells.
In Carim, the saints give voice to the ancient tales. They memorize countless cumbersome sacred books and read them in sonorous tones, a function for which they are widely renowned.

A ring bestowed upon the Deacons of the Cathedral of the Deep.
Increases all dark damage by 5%.
In the Cathedral slumber things most terrible, and as such, the deacons require a grand narrative, to ensure they do not falter in their duty. A philosophy, to ward away the madness beckoned by the grotesqueries at hand.

Ring of the moon deity Gwyndolin, youngest son of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Adds 3 slots for attunement.
Gwyndolin, also known as the Dark Sun, commands the Darkmoon Knights, and bestows this ring upon the best of them.

A special ring given to those who are deemed fit to undertake the journey of discovery in Vinheim, home of sorcery.
Increases all magic damage by 15%.
Apropos to the Dragon School, the seal depicts an everlasting dragon. A bellowing dragon symbolizes the true nature of the consumate sorcerer.

The Witch of Izalith and her daughters, scorched by the flame of chaos, thaught humans the art of pyromancy and offered them this ring.
Increases all fire damage by 15%.
Every pyromancer is familiar with the parable that tells of the witches espousing the need to fear the flame, and teaching the art of pyromancy to men in hopes that they might learn to control it.

Lord Gwyn's firstborn, who inherited the sunlight, once wore this ancient ring. Increases all lightning damage by 15%.
Lord Gwyn's firstborn was a god of war, but his foolishness led to a loss of the annals, and rescinding of his deific status. Today, even his name is not known.

Ring associated with Hawkeye Gough, one of the Four Knights of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Extends the range of arrows.
In his later years, the giant Gough was blinded, but this did not prevent him from striking down a calamitous dragon with his Greatbow.

Ring associated with the Lord's Blade Ciaran, one of the Four Knights of Gwyn, the First Lord.
Boosts critical attacks.
The masked Ciaran was the only woman to serve in Gwyn's Four Knights, and her curved sword granted a swift death to any and all enemies of the throne.

A gold ring depicting a snake that could have been, but never was, a dragon. Fallen foes are more likely to drop items.
Snakes are known as creatures of great avarice, devouring prey even larger than themselves by swallowing them whole.
If one's shackles are cause for discontent, perhaps it is time for some old-fashioned greed.

A gold ring depicting a snake that could have been, but never was, a dragon. Fallen foes are more likely to drop items.
Snakes are known as creatures of great avarice, devouring prey even larger than themselves by swallowing them whole.
If one's shackles are cause for discontent, perhaps it is time for some old-fashioned greed.

A gold ring depicting a snake that could have been, but never was, a dragon. Fallen foes are more likely to drop items.
Snakes are known as creatures of great avarice, devouring prey even larger than themselves by swallowing them whole.
If one's shackles are cause for discontent, perhaps it is time for some old-fashioned greed.

A silver ring depicting a snake that could have been, but never was, a dragon. Fallen foes yield more souls.
Snakes are known as creatures of great avarice, devouring prey even larger than themselves by swallowing them whole.
If one's shackles are cause for discontent, perhaps it is time for some old-fashioned greed.

A silver ring depicting a snake that could have been, but never was, a dragon. Fallen foes yield more souls.
Snakes are known as creatures of great avarice, devouring prey even larger than themselves by swallowing them whole.
If one's shackles are cause for discontent, perhaps it is time for some old-fashioned greed.

A silver ring depicting a snake that could have been, but never was, a dragon. Fallen foes yield more souls.
Snakes are known as creatures of great avarice, devouring prey even larger than themselves by swallowing them whole.
If one's shackles are cause for discontent, perhaps it is time for some old-fashioned greed.

Ring associated with Gwynevere, princess of sunlight and eldest daughter of Gwyn, the First Lord.
The ring is vaguely warm, like a beam of sunlight, and gradually restores HP.
Gwynevere left her home with a great many other deities, and became a wife and mother, raising several heavenly children.

Silver ring depicting a leaping feline. Prevents damage from falling.
In the Age of Gods, or possibly just following it, an old cat was said to speak a human tongue, with the voice of an old woman, and the form of a fanciful immortal.

One of Courland's transposed wonders. Derived from the soul of a Soulfeeder.
Increases physical damage by 15% but compromises damage absorption by 10%.
The Soulfeeder was a beast that insatiably absorbed souls to feed its own power. Even after its accursed corpse was burned, it is said that the pungent stench of souls left the air permanently stained.

One of the illusory rings worn by the Hollows of Londor.
Take the appearance of a phantom.
The Hollows of Londor are wretchedly aged, fraught with deceit, and dubiously secretive. It is no wonder that they are deeply detested.

Ring worn by warriors of the sand kingdom, Carthus. Slightly boosts dexterity and obscures the wearer while rolling.
The sword technique of Carthus allows for fluid movement with a curved sword. Masters of the technique are said to dazzle their opponents by moving as weightlessly as a grain of sand. They live for their High Lord Wolnir, conqueror of most kingdoms known to their people.

Ring engraved with a portrait of a knight. Increases strength.
In Lothric, the Knight has long been considered one of the Three Pillars of the king's rule, and were thus allowed to rear dragons.

Ring engraved with a portrait of a hunter. Increases dexterity.
The hunters serve Lothric on the fringes and in the shadows. For generations, rulers of Lothric have relied especially upon the Black Hand hunters to punish enemies in ways that the king's Three Pillars cannot.

Ring of the savage Tsorig, more commonly known as the Knight Slayer.
Enemies lose more stamina when guarding attacks.
Long ago, Tsorig engaged the guardians of an ancient city in a bloody confrontation, and returned with their rings as his prize, still frozen on their dismembered fingers.

Ring depicting a hand grasping a blue stone. Increases magic damage by 15%, but compromises damage absorption by 10%.
An old fable in Londor claims that the lure of the clutch ring reaches out to the crestfallen, who might otherwise be overcome by despair.

Ring depicting a hand grasping a yellow stone. Increases lightning damage by 15%, but compromises damage absorption by 10%.
An old fable in Londor claims that the lure of the clutch ring reaches out to the crestfallen, who might otherwise be overcome by despair.

Ring depicting a hand grasping a red stone. Increases fire damage by 15%, but compromises damage absorption by 10%.
An old fable in Londor claims that the lure of the clutch ring reaches out to the crestfallen, who might otherwise be overcome by despair.

Ring depicting a hand grasping a purple stone. Increases dark damage by 15%, but compromises damage absorption by 10%.
An old fable in Londor claims that the lure of the clutch ring reaches out to the crestfallen, who might otherwise be overcome by despair.

Ring of Raime the traitor. Reduces stamina loss when blocking with shield.
Raime was an agile swordsman who served King Vendrick, but after resigning from his post, he reconsidered his way of life and was born again as a stalwart warrior.

Ring of Flynn, the eulogized thief. Lowering equip load increases attack power.
Flynn fought with the wind on his side, and was a hero among the weak and poor, yet even his admirers knew that it was little more than an idyllic fable.

Made from materials strange to Lothric, this ring was said to be found in a fallen star. The strange aura it emits grants the wearer increased strength, proportional to the weight they carry. Even the greatest scholars of Vinheim could not identify the properties of such an item, as it seems to lack magic entirely.
Gain more strength by increasing your equip load.

Portion of a steel chain used to restrain Gundyr. Gain vigor, endurance, and vitality, but take extra damage.
A prisoner is one who has staked everything on a belief, a proclivity most apparent in the greatest of champions.

One of the illusory rings worn by the Hollows of Londor.
Retain human appearance while Hollow.
The Hollows of Londor are wretchedly aged, fraught with deceit, and dubiously secretive. It is no wonder that they are deeply detested.

Ring of Sir Yorgh, who sought the blood of a dragon and invaded Shulva. Can deflect spells.
When Sir Yorgh faced Sinh, the slumbering dragon, he drew blood with a flash of his steel, but Sinh responded by spewing forth the poison that had long brewed within him, blanketing the city in a miasmic cloud.

Ring bestowed upon the Fingers of Rosaria, invaders who seek tongues for their goddess.
Hides the presence of the wearer when far away.
It is said that Rosaria, the mother of rebirth, was robbed of her tongue by her firstborn, and has been waiting for their return ever since.

This ring captured the foul spirit of an evil eye, a creature that ravaged Astora.
Absorb HP from each defeated foe.
The horrid spirit nearly destroyed Astora, but was eventually defeated by "the sword of one most noble."

This ring captured the foul spirit of an evil eye, a creature that ravaged Astora.
Absorb HP from each defeated foe.
The horrid spirit nearly destroyed Astora, but was eventually defeated by "the sword of one most noble."

This ring captured the foul spirit of an evil eye, a creature that ravaged Astora.
Absorb HP from each defeated foe.
The horrid spirit nearly destroyed Astora, but was eventually defeated by "the sword of one most noble."

A ring made from the orange eye of a calamitous dragon. Receive double damage.
This ring has no useful powers, and is merely a symbol of dragon worship, a thing quietly passed down amongst its most fervent adherents, some of whom become convinced the task has been bestowed upon them as a sacred duty.

A ring given to Undead Legion of Farron. Reduces Skill FP consumption.
The Abyss Watchers, for their hunting, required a sword technique that went beyond any existing art. Wolf's blood provided just that, and this ring further extends the effect.

A malformed ring left by Aldrich, Saint of the Deep.
Recovers HP with successive attacks.
Aldrich, infamous for his appetite for flesh, apparently had the desire to share with others his joy of imbibing the final shudders of life while luxuriating in his victim's screams.

A malformed ring left by Aldrich, Saint of the Deep.
Recovers FP with successive attacks.
Aldrich, infamous for his appetite for flesh, apparently had the desire to share with others his joy of imbibing the final shudders of life while luxuriating in his victim's screams.

Protects its wearer from various ailments. Increases effect of status ailments.
The effects of this ring, which incites all known disorders of this world, are greatly feared. Even the sorcerer who forged the ring sealed it away following its creation.

A ring that greatly enhances miracle strength. Increases effective range of miracles.
A gift from the gods awarded for devotion and perserverance. The original owner is no longer of this world, yet the ring remains an object of faith.

Ring given to knights of the Way of White. Depicts Allfather Lloyd's Sword of Law.
Boosts attack power when HP is full.
Much time has passed since the worship of Lloyd was common in the Way of White. The clerics of Carim had always strongly asserted that Lloyd was a derivative fraud, and that the Allfather title was self-proclaimed.

Ring given to knights of the Way of White. Depicts Allfather Lloyd's Shield of Caste.
Boosts damage absorption when HP is full.
Much time has passed since the worship of Lloyd was common in the Way of White. The clerics of Carim had always strongly asserted that Lloyd was a derivative fraud, and that the Allfather title was self-proclaimed.

Masks one's presence from adversaries. Hides the wearer from Dark Spirits at a distance.
The wearer's presence is obscured, concealing their very existence from invaders of that world. However, if permitted to get close, the effect will fade.

A green ring crafted from shards. Increases HP restored by Estus Flask.
This ring was entrusted to a certain Fire Keeper, but in the end she never met her champion, and the ensuing tragic farce became a favorite tale of the masses.

Gray crystalline ring crafted from shards. Increases FP restored by Ashen Estus Flask.
Once a treasure brought before Lothric's Queen, she had it enshrined in the Cemetery of Untended Graves, so that one day an Unkindled might profit from its use.

An old ring with a seal depicting a horse's hoof. Boosts kick effect.
Unbreakable Patches adored this ring and the feeling that it gave it him when he kicked his marks into the depths of treacherous traps, but suffered no shortage of ridicule from his associates for relying so heavily on the tired old trick.
But who is the sorrier? The horse who knows only to kick, or the fool who approaches the old beast without thought?

Ring worn by warriors of the sand kingdom, Carthus. Boosts rolling invincibility, at the cost of defense.
The sword technique of Carthus allows for fluid movement with a curved sword. Masters of the technique are said to dazzle their opponents by moving as weightlessly as a grain of sand. They live for their High Lord Wolnir, conqueror of most kingdoms known to their people.

A divine ring granted to the Darkmoon Gwyndolin in his youth.
Causes males to perform female actions, and vice-versa.
Gwyndolin was raised like a daughter through the aura of the moon, and was said to behave like a sullen brooding goddess.

Bewitched ring that Pontiff Sulyvahn bestowed upon his knights.
Boosts attacks, as long as attacking persists.
Knights who peer into the black orb are lured into battles of death, transformed into frenzied beasts. No wonder the Pontiff only provides these rings to those dispatched to foreign lands.

Wearer's will to fight is converted into strength. Boosts defense, as long as attacking persists.
The unnatural ability of a late hero dwells within this ring, the use of which was permitted to only a select and valiant few.

Wearer's will to fight is converted into strength. Boosts stamina recovery speed, as long as attacking persists.
The unnatural ability of a late hero dwells within this ring, the use of which was permitted to only a select and valiant few.

Wearer's will to fight is converted into strength. Boosts spells, as long as attacking persists.
The unnatural ability of a late hero dwells within this ring, the use of which was permitted to only a select and valiant few.

Bewitched ring that Pontiff Sulyvahn bestowed upon his knights.
Increases your stamina damage dealt by 15%.
Knights who peer into the black orb are lured into battles of death, transformed into frenzied beasts. No wonder the Pontiff only provides these rings to those dispatched to foreign lands.

Wearer's will to fight is converted into strength. Recovers FP with successive attacks.
The unnatural ability of a late hero dwells within this ring, the use of which was permitted to only a select and valiant few.

Wearer's will to fight is converted into strength. Adds extra damage with successive attacks.
The unnatural ability of a late hero dwells within this ring, the use of which was permitted to only a select and valiant few.

Wearer's will to fight is converted into strength. Increases drop rate with successive attacks.
The unnatural ability of a late hero dwells within this ring, the use of which was permitted to only a select and valiant few.

Ring of Oceiros, former king of Lothric. Reduces damage from backstabs.
In his later years, Oceiros became fascinated with dragons. After going mad, he was more commonly known as the Consumed King. Many assassins were dispatched to his domain, but none returned.
The Consumed King ascribed his resilience to the divine protection of the dragon scale.

An otherworldly ring, crafted from seemingly indestructible alloy and luminescent gems. The blood-red crystals have been fashioned in the image of the Father of the Abyss, and can grant the wearer but a fraction of his power.
Increases damage of all dark magic by 15%.

Embrace the power of Anse Syen.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts magic attacks by 10%. Boosts FP regen by 4. Reduces sorcery FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Graz'zt.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts dark attacks by 10%. Increases attack power as long as attacking persists. Reduces sorcery FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Orcus.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts fire attacks by 10%. Boosts physical, dark, magic and lightning defences by 5%. Reduces conjuration FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Gamosh-Ra.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts lightning attacks by 10%. Grants 20 SP recovery. Reduces miracle FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Zuggtmoy.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts blood defence by 200. Boosts dark attacks by 10% and LCK by 3 levels. Reduces miracle FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Polarri.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts frost defence and frost attacks by 200. Grants an additional boost in stamina damage by 50%. Boosts dark attacks by 10%. Reduces conjuration FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Asmodeus.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts all weapon attacks by 12%. Reduces weapon stamina consumption by 12%. Increases your maximum equip load by 12%.

Embrace the power of Focalor.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts magic and lightning defences by 5% and lightning attacks by 10%. Increases Estus and Ashen Estus healing by 25%. Reduces sorcery FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Cathbad.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Applies 75 magic damage on roll. Boosts magic attacks by 10%. Reduces conjuration FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Rad'Noj.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts your soul gain by 5%. Boosts magic attacks by 10%. Reduces miracle FP consumption by 10%.

Ring from an ancient land. The Lord of Sunlight forged the first alliance of giants and humans, combining their strengths to foster an elite force of giant knights. This ring has lost some of its luster, but the magic within remains, allowing the wearer to enhance his body with the strength, stability, and longevity of giants.
Increases physical attacks by 7.5%, increases poise by 10 and adds 10 stamina recovery.

A cursed ring depicting a demon eye. If it is tranquility that you seek, then you should never have left your home. If you seek strife, then fair enough, but no need to overdo it.
Easier to be detected by enemies and draws their attention. Adds red eyes effect to player.

This special ring crafted in an Eastern land is made of gold, but with a wood grain crest on its surface. Agents of subterfuge in this faraway land are particularly fond of the dark gold wood grain, which grants invulnerability to backsteps, while at low equipment load.

This ring, thought to be a myth, represents the greatest blessing bestowed on mortals by the Goddess Velka, Mother of Sin.
Increases stamina recovery and resistances. Reduces weapon stamina consumption and fall damage.
“She will see only that which walks, ineffable, impeccable and with no fear. When her eye is upon you, only then and only there, you shall have peace.”

A ring originating from foreign lands. Said to grant the wielder the power of its previous wielders.
Increases STR, DEX, INT, FTH and LCK by 2.
"Soul of the mind, key to life's ether. Soul of the lost, withdrawn from its vessel. Let strength be granted, so the world might be mended."

A ring affixed with one of the charms made by the paladins of Lloyd. An unlikely application of a common tool.
Blocks Estus recovery within a limited area at random time frames.

A ring made of petrified dragon scale imbued with the power of the skies. This ring is favored by the battlemages of the windswept peaks who value speed over abundance.
Greatly increase your casting speed, while doubling the cost of spells.
Increase your casting speed by 99 but increase the FP cost of all spells by double.

Embrace the power of Sabnock.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts physical attacks by 10%. Grants a massive poise boost. Reduces miracle FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Abaddon.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts all damage types by 3%. Increases the amount that Estus and Ashen Estus heals by 30%. Increases item discovery by 25%.

Embrace the power of Malphas.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts physical attacks by 10%. Increases casting speed by 20. Reduces sorcery FP consumption by 10%.

Embrace the power of Vepar.
You can only wear one Shell at a time.
Boosts physical attacks by 10%. Grants a boost to all absorption by 10%. Reduces conjuration FP consumption by 10%.

A ring given to an elite few among the congregation of Allfather Lloyd. Harnessing many powers, this ring is a symbol of humility and loyalty to the order.
Adds HP regen, bolsters defense by 10% and adds an additional spell slot.

A ring of the bloodline of Griggs, apprentice to Logan. It was passed down to the nephew of Griggs after the fall of Seath. While his name is forgotten, he was celebrated for his skill and dedication as a spy in the employ of the School of the Dragon. Pledged to never take this ring off, he imparted several charms upon it which acted as boons in the fulfillment of his duties.
Grants additional SP and FP regeneration, adds 1 additional spell slot and adds 5% additional magic damage.

A ring made to prove membership to the brotherhood, though rarely used in this capacity.
Grants the wearer silent footsteps, reduced damage from falling, an additional 10% to max stamina and reduces equip load.

This ring creates a kinship with the creatures of the abyss within the wearer, mimicking their covetous and a bottomless hunger for living blood.
Adds passive HP regeneration and heals the wearer when striking with a weapon attack.

A ring given by Wolnir to only his foremost battlemages. Once used to assist in the construction of his desert palaces, it later was used solely for destruction.
Boosts physical damage by 10%.
Sands made poor foundation but Wolnir would not be stifled by such triviality. His geomancers toiled for generations fusing the sands into stone. Later he much preferred this process reversed upon the stones of his neighbors.

A warm, blackened ring that drops an endless trickle of ash.
Increases fire damage by 10%.

A strange, dull ring that seems to reflect no light of its surfaces.
Increases dark damage by 10%.

A humming, vibrant ring that crackles with sparks.
Increases lightning damage by 10%.

A cool, shimmering ring covered in tiny blue crystals.
Increases magic damage by 10%.

A simple ring used by scholars for manual tasks.
Increases physical damage by 5%.
Grand scholar Car'el was known for cleaning the entire library without ever leaving his study.

Recovered from the desolation of Forossa, this ring hid the secret of the Lion knights' martial prowess.
Increases physical damage by 15%.
"Strike the empty air with such might that even it shall flee from you."
